snippet: The state has a long record of taking on the federal government in long-shot battles, and its most recent fight over same-sex marriage sets it apart even from conservative neighbors.
abstract: Alabama, though not unique among conservative states in opposing same-sex marriage, is the only state where probate judges who would issue such licenses were instructed to disregard federal court order that defies popular majority; such defiant, brazen and often hopeless campaigns are practically hard-wired into state's makeup.

byline.original: By CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and SHAILA DEWAN
byline.contributor: Campbell Robertson reported from Birmingham, and Shaila Dewan from New York. Richard Fausset contributed reporting from Montgomery, Ala., and Kalyn Wolfe from Mobile, Ala.

lead_paragraph: The state has a long record of taking on the federal government in long-shot battles, and its most recent fight over same-sex marriage sets it apart even from conservative neighbors.

headline.main: In Defiance on Gay Marriage, Alabama Sets Itself Far Apart
headline.print_headline: A State Apart: Gay Marriage and Alabama

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
